           <h1 id="ctl00_ctl00_cphBody_cpTemplateBody_lblHead">
            New laws in the UK aim to tackle child marriage
           </h1>
           <div class="MainBodyContainer" id="ctl00_ctl00_cphBody_cpTemplateBody_lblBody">
            <p>
             <strong>
              This summer the UK Government passed a new law to protect victims of forced marriage in the UK, with a particular focus on children and adolescent girls.
             </strong>
            </p>
            <p>
             It is now a criminal offence to force someone into a marriage, male or female,and can be met with a hefty prison sentence. The new law protects anyone in England and Wales who is a victim of forced marriage, and importantly, also extends to British nationals at risk of being forced to marry abroad.
            </p>
            <p>
             The Home Offices Forced Marriage Unit (FMU) reported that in 2012 they dealt with 1485 cases*. The FMU also disclosed that the overwhelming majority of cases they handled affected girls, with 82% involving female victims.
            </p>
            <p>
             Forced marriage is clearly an issue in the UK, though due to its nature it is one that remains cloaked in secrecy. The true extent ofthis harmfulpractice is hard to estimate. But across the world the figures are even more shocking.
            </p>
            <p>
             A study by the United Nations Population Fund revealed that approximately 14 million girls are at risk of forced marriage every single year**. Like much of Plan's
             <a href="http://www.plan-uk.org/because-i-am-a-girl/resources/" target="_blank" title="Resources">
              advocacy and campaigns work on the issue
             </a>
             , the report highlighted how child marriage and forced marriage damages lives, limits the access girls have to education, and inhibits their opportunity to lead healthy and fulfilling lives.
            </p>
            <h2>
             The impact of child marriage and forced marriage
            </h2>
            <p>
             Girls who are forced to marry experience many negative consequences aside from the emotional damage of being married to someone they dont know long before they are physically and emotionally prepared for such an event.
            </p>
            <ul>
             <li>
              <strong>
               Higher mortality.
              </strong>
              Victims of child marriage have much higher rates of mortality than girls of the same age who are unwed. They are more likely to fall pregnant before their bodies are ready, and the biggest killer of girls aged 15-19 in developing nations is childbirth.
              <br/>
             </li>
             <li>
              <strong>
               Poor health.
              </strong>
              This is related in part to the above point. Victims of forced marriage have higher rates of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections. One study in Kenya revealed that adolescent brides had double the average rate of HIV infection. They are also more likely to suffer repeated physical, sexual and emotional abuse, all of which damages their health. The nature of the power relationship in child marriage means that girls are not able to speak up or defend themselves.
              <br/>
             </li>
             <li>
              <strong>
               Loss of control.
              </strong>
              The nature of the power relationship in child marriage means that girls are not able to speak up or defend themselves. This loss of control in their own lives due to the forced marriage leads to social isolation, a lack of participation amongst peer groups and their community. The situation also restricts the childs access to educational opportunities, health information, and medical services.
              <br/>
             </li>
             <li>
              <strong>
               Higher rates of illiteracy.
              </strong>
              Once a girl is married, any education she was involved in tends to cease. Also a girls current level of education has a correlation with her likelihood of being forced to marry. Girls with no education are 3 times more likely to marry young than those with a secondary education. Sadly this continues a cycle, as children of young, poorly educated mothers are more likely to drop out of school and be a victim of child marriage.
             </li>
            </ul>
            <p>
             In the UK and other developed nations laws are in place to protect girls and women from forced marriage. But around the world in developing nations there are no such laws, and in fact there are many laws that expressly permit girls to be married younger than boys.
             <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-29216141" target="_blank" title="Proposal to reduce Bangladesh marriageable age">
              In Bangladesh, the government has proposedto lower the legal age for girls to marry
             </a>
             . In response, there is an active campaign to block any changes.
            </p>
            <p>
             The devastation that forced marriage causes cant be allowed to continue. With your help we can create changefor millions of girls, enabling them to live a happy and fulfilling childhood before choosing if and who they marry.
            </p>
            <p>
             <strong>
              We campaign to protect girls around the world and you can help us. Do you believe enough is enough?
              <a href="#" title="Our work to end child marriage">
               Find out more about our fight to end forced marriage
              </a>
              and
              <a href="http://e-activist.com/ea-action/action?ea.client.id=59&amp;ea.campaign.id=22752&amp;__utma=31548671.199142175.1403000087.1414753843.1414759845.384&amp;__utmb=31548671.14.10.1414759845&amp;__utmc=31548671&amp;__utmx=-&amp;__utmz=31548671.1414153276.365.22.utmcsr=google|utmccn=(organic)|utmcmd=organic|utmctr=(not%20provided)&amp;__utmv=-&amp;__utmk=156695289" title="BIAAG Join the Campaign">
               lend your support today
              </a>
              .
             </strong>
            </p>
            <p align="center">
             <a href="http://e-activist.com/ea-action/action?ea.client.id=59&amp;ea.campaign.id=22752&amp;__utma=31548671.199142175.1403000087.1414753843.1414759845.384&amp;__utmb=31548671.14.10.1414759845&amp;__utmc=31548671&amp;__utmx=-&amp;__utmz=31548671.1414153276.365.22.utmcsr=google|utmccn=(organic)|utmcmd=organic|utmctr=(not%20provided)&amp;__utmv=-&amp;__utmk=156695289" title="BIAAG Join the Campaign">
              <img alt="join-the-campaign-large-red" src="http://www.plan-uk.org/assets/images/hotspot/large-rounded-buttons/join-the-campaign-large-red.gif" style="BORDER-BOTTOM: 0px solid; TEXT-ALIGN: center; BORDER-LEFT: 0px solid; MARGIN: 0px; BORDER-TOP: 0px solid; BORDER-RIGHT: 0px solid"/>
             </a>
            </p>
            <p>
             <strong>
              References
              <br/>
             </strong>
             *
             <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/141823/Stats_2012.pdf" title="Forced Marriage Unit statistics">
              Forced Marriage Statistics 2012, Forced Marriage Unit
             </a>
             <br/>
             **
             <a href="http://www.unfpa.org/public/home/publications/pid/12166" title="UNFPA Marrying Too Young">
              Marrying Too Young, UNFPA
             </a>
            </p>
           </div>
